title: Lesson Study Overview
originalHtml:
​

Welcome to the Ranking Evidence lesson study, the spring lesson study for the SMLC Source-Based Argument Secondary course. We are excited to share this experience with you. This lesson study focuses on the Ranking Evidence lesson sequence.

This lesson sequence focuses on supporting students in evaluating the quality and relevance of evidence to support a claim. As with all NWP lesson sequences, this resource layers annotated reading, reflective writing, and critical thinking surrounding a topic. For the lesson study you are invited try out the lesson sequence with your students, reflect on your learners’ experiences, and gather student writing to plan for next instructional steps. You can access the full lesson sequence for each text set option here.

​

What is a Lesson Study?

A lesson study is a collaborative approach to improving learning and instruction by exploring, applying, and reflecting on a lesson sequence. Lesson studies are designed around a cycle of instruction that builds understanding, flexibility, and responsiveness to learners.

The overarching goals of Lesson Study are to build pathways that enable continual growth of the knowledge, interpersonal resources, and motivation required to improve teaching and learning. Teachers’ agency is honored, and their efficacy increases as they design and witness ever-improving cycles of instruction.

​

How Will the Lesson Study Work?

​

In this lesson study course, the chapters are organized by "lessons" in the lesson sequence. Each chapter in the course provides an opportunity for you to reflect on your plans for and/or experiences with teaching a lesson in the lesson sequence. As you post responses on your discussion group, please also reply to each other offering appreciation, asking questions, and adding new ideas that spark discussion.

If possible, plan on teaching the lesson sequence during the lesson study window. That will provide the best opportunity for real-time reflection and collaboration; also, you will need to bring student writing from this lesson study to the in-person statewide Regroup Meeting on March 8th. However, depending on your schedule and curricular requirements, the lesson study timeframe may not work for your teaching context. In order to support everyone's participation, we are including prompts for those of you will be teaching it between March 3rd and 23rd, as well as prompts for those of you who will be teaching it later this year.

  • If you are teaching the lesson sequence now or have already taught it, we want to hear all about how your learners respond to the activities. What works for them? What surprises you? What questions come up?

  • If you are teaching it later this year, anticipate and plan for the application of the activities with your learners. This might look like you trying out the activities yourself and responding to the prompts from your own perspective as a learner, and thinking through how your learners will respond to the activities. What might work for your learners? What might surprise you? What questions do you have?

Course Credential

This credential for the course is six learning hours, to be completed between March 3rd and March 23rd.

To earn NWP’s SMLC Ranking Evidence credential, you will:

  • Post to all discussions, respond to others, and submit a reflection about your experience in the discussions

  • Submit a final reflection

​
